      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(PlayingCard rightSidePlayingCard)
        compareTo automatically gets called by methods like Collections.sort(). Here, we can specify how we want our class to be sorted. When calling this method, we want to rank the cards lowest to highest. So, the card "1 of CLUBS" will always be first and "13 of SPADES" will always be last. compareTo will call two other methods. First compareSuit, then compareRank if the suits are the same. We want to organize cards from lowest to highest. If the left side playing card (this object) is lower than the right side playing card, we will want to return -1. If it is larger, we will want to return 1. If the cards are the same, we will return 0.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<PlayingCard>
        Parameters:
        rightSidePlayingCard - the PlayingCard object on the right side of the comparison
        Returns:
        int -1, 0, or 1 depending on the playing card.

      • compareRank

        public int compareRank(int rightSideRank)
        When comparing ranks, we are comparing ints. This means that we can use the normal comparison operators of less than , greater than, and ==.
        Parameters:
        rightSideRank - the rank of the playing card on the right
        Returns:
        int either a -1, 0, or 1

      • compareSuit

        public int compareSuit(Suit rightSideSuit)
        Playing cards are typically sorted with CLUBS being the lowest, then DIAMONDS, HEARTS, and SPADES. To do this, make some if statements that check this.suit and compare it to the righSideSuit.
        Parameters:
        rightSideSuit - the suit of the playing card on the right side
        Returns:
        int either a -1, 0, or 1

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
